0.00.text:
There's some British food
with some really weird names.

3.03.text: And we're gonna eat some of it.

4.56.text: (Barry and Jamie) Let's talk about that.

15.92.text:
Welcome to a very special
episode of the show

18.47.text:
with special guest, Barry
and Jamie from Sorted Food!

23.64.text:
- So special.
- Thank you very much.

26.51.text: If you are human and you like food,

29.02.text: you should subscribe to their channel.

30.38.text:
(Jamie) It's a great thing.
Everybody has to eat.

32.18.text: But you don't have to be British.

34.01.text: But you guys have special knowledge.

37.09.text: Well, we think you have special knowledge

39.27.text:
- just because of your accents.
- Yeah, it helps.

41.51.text:
It does make you sound cleverer
if you are British, instantly.

44.87.text:
But I don't think you can say that.
No, we can say that.

47.91.text: Oh no, we can, 'cause we're British.

52.29.text: but we all think that you're geniuses,

54.80.text: and you should roll with that.

56.29.text:
- Well, I know that you guys are--
- What do you mean by "think"?

58.87.text:
You guys are good with food.
We do know that.

61.60.text:
- Yes.
- You're food geniuses, at least.

63.45.text:
- Uh-huh.
- And I'm good at tasting food.

65.90.text:
What we've heard is that
there's a lot of British foods

73.01.text:
So what we've asked them to do
is to bring some of these foods

77.77.text:
- and teach us what they actually are.
- But the game is,

81.16.text: you guys are gonna tell us about a food.

83.28.text:
You're gonna just say
what it is and describe it,

85.34.text:
and then we have to guess
if it's real or fake.

88.15.text: My understanding is that you have

89.43.text:
both the real and the fake versions
for us to taste and see.

94.10.text:
I think it's gonna be a little bit tricky.
Should we get started?

96.54.text:
Well, we should. But first,
let's say what's at stake,

98.52.text:
- because the loser--
- We're going against each other.

101.35.text:
It's Rhett versus Link,
and the loser has to eat

103.85.text:
- an entire spoonful of Marmite.
- (man gags)

106.43.text: Ladies and gentlemen, it's time to play...

108.48.text: (Rhett) Is That Really a British Food?

111.60.text: Or Did Some British Dudes Just Make It Up?

119.26.text:
This one's-- I think
this is really obvious.

121.56.text: It is quite an obvious one.

124.10.text:
- Have you heard of bubble and squeak?
- Bubble and squeak.

126.68.text:
Bubble and squeak-- that's what
they called us in high school.

128.60.text:
- (Barry and Jamie laugh)
- This is just simply, it's a--

132.29.text:
I'm trying to figure out
which one I would want to be.

135.37.text:
- Am I bubble or squeak?
- I don't know.

137.78.text:
This is something you usually
have on a Monday,

139.42.text:
purely because over the weekend
you've had your roast dinner.

146.59.text:
and you've had your
full English breakfast.

148.17.text:
And you basically take all
the leftovers from those two,

150.71.text:
merge them in one, and
you create bubble and squeak.

152.79.text:
So bubble and squeak is
basically mashed potato,

156.98.text: some bacons, some onions, and some garlic,

158.95.text:
mashed together into
little kind of patties.

162.28.text: Where's the bubble and the squeak come at?

165.46.text:
- once you work it out.
- Nowhere, if they made it up.

168.16.text:
- So we'll give our answers in unison?
- Okay. We're good to go?

171.96.text:
Okay. Is it real or is it fake?
In three, two, one.

179.50.text:
So only thing that's up for grabs
is learning something.

181.83.text:
- Okay.
- You still think it's real?

184.00.text:
Well, it definitely looks
like what you described.

188.13.text:
- is real.
- Yeah, it's real! Yeah, it's real!

191.59.text:
It's basically like a baked potato
in the shape of a burger.

197.42.text:
I made it this morning,
and I'm not gonna lie.

199.46.text: I'm a bit proud of these.

200.65.text:
- Well, you've said that--
- Boy, that tastes good.

202.22.text:
- Bubble and squeak.
- They're done really well.

203.57.text: But it's not bubbling or squeaking.

204.89.text:
No, so the bubble
and squeak is basically--

206.56.text:
it's apparently the noise
the cabbage makes

209.65.text: while it's in the pan. It squeaks.

211.15.text:
- You wash your cooking there.
- I wasn't there for that.

212.54.text:
And the noise you make
a couple hours later?

216.57.text: Second up. Now, I'm pretty sure

218.05.text:
you've actually heard of this one,
because it is so popular.

220.04.text:
- Toad in the hole.
- (Rhett chuckles) That's tricky.

225.84.text: So this is a dish which we have in England

228.21.text:
where we take sausages
and we put them in a pudding.

230.71.text:
But that pudding has
to come from Yorkshire, okay?

234.37.text:
It's a pudding, and it has
to come from Yorkshire.

236.59.text:
- So it has to be a Yorkshire pudding.
- That's a place.

239.23.text:
And we put the sausages
within the pudding.

242.07.text:
And then we usually serve that
with maybe some mashed potatoes,

246.74.text: I see the theme here-- mashed potatoes.

248.65.text:
So the toad is the sausage,
and it makes a hole in the pudding?

252.24.text:
- It's a toad in the hole.
- Okay.

254.83.text: Is it real? In three, two, one...

261.50.text:
So we've made some here for you.
This is what they look like.

265.26.text:
- These are little miniature ones.
- Oh, so it's like a...

271.68.text:
- You made this.
- This is real?

272.93.text:
- We made this.
- That is real.

275.01.text:
(Rhett) You know why
we're so good at this?

276.43.text:
Because we share a lineage.
My people are from where you're from.

281.93.text:
- I said we're so good at it.
- Oh yeah.

284.61.text: Who are your people? Do we know them?

286.50.text:
- It's a small country.
- The Scottish?

291.70.text:
- They are still our people.
- Just.

294.41.text:
- They don't want to be, really.
- So we're two for two.

295.90.text:
- Two for two.
- We're blindly guessing,

298.04.text:
but we're doing a good job
at it and we're tied.

300.87.text:
- Okay.
- That, too, tasted very good.

304.90.text:
- I like how you guys--
- I made that one.

308.24.text:
Okay, so this one is
a bat on a sticky wicket.

320.02.text: Oh, come on. This one, we a nice--

322.10.text: It's kind of a street food in the UK.

323.44.text:
- Mm-hmm.
- We're not very well known...

324.94.text:
- Sure it is.
- ...for our street food.

326.41.text:
But we're big fans of cricket,
hence the "sticky wicket."

329.16.text:
- Oh yeah.
- Yep. You know cricket?

331.20.text: No. Well, I know that it's a sport,

332.99.text: but I don't know what a wicket is.

334.19.text: It's basically as boring as baseball.

337.44.text:
They don't have gloves, though.
That makes it more interesting.

339.41.text: Their bat is called a wicket?

341.28.text:
No, the wicket is what
you have to hit with the ball.

343.91.text:
- That's behind the bat.
- Behind the bat.

345.83.text:
- Huh?
- Basically, a bat on a sticky wicket--

349.16.text:
Okay, so you made this one up.
Even the word "wicket" is made up.

352.74.text:
- (Barry and Jamie laugh)
- No, I've heard that before.

354.41.text: So it's basically a chicken on a stick

356.96.text:
with this really kind of
cool curry glaze on it.

359.34.text:
Obviously, the UK is well-known
for its curries as well.

361.73.text:
- Yep.
- So it's a combination of those two.

364.69.text: It's not a bat, as you all know.

367.66.text: It looks like a bat from wicket.

371.18.text:
I thought the meat was
supposed to be like a bat meat.

378.78.text:
I was gonna say "fake,"
but then I heard you say it, so...

382.03.text:
- Oh, okay.
- I'm going with real.

383.50.text:
Oh. Split. So we've
made some for you here.

387.49.text:
- What do you think?
- There we go.

391.41.text:
This is something you got
from Target or something.

393.41.text:
- This is fake.
- No, it's fake. It's definitely fake.

397.13.text:
It does look like
a bat on a stick, though.

399.85.text:
- It's barbecue on some chicken tenders.
- Yeah.

404.93.text:
- Why are you laughing?
- (crew member) You can eat it.

406.34.text:
- How did you prepare this?
- (crew member) It's okay.

409.71.text:
- We didn't make it at all.
- (Jamie laughs)

411.38.text:
You got them to throw
together this nastiness.

414.38.text:
I put that in my mouth, and the
look of the crew was like, "No!"

417.85.text:
But I do feel like I need
to clear something up,

419.51.text:
because cricket is real
and wickets are real.

423.10.text:
And sticky wicket is when
you're in a difficult circumstance.

427.09.text:
- You're stuck on a wicket.
- Yeah, you're on a sticky wicket.

429.98.text:
Well, Link's in a sticky wicket,
'cause he's down one.

433.73.text:
- Bring it on, boys.
- Okay, so number four:

439.45.text: So this is one of my nan's favorites,

442.20.text: 'cause it originated in World War II.

444.70.text:
You know, there was rationing.
It was hard times.

447.45.text: So people were trying to club together

448.92.text:
and find the kind of foods that
they could make for themselves.

451.20.text: And so it's made up of chips--

453.76.text: or, you'd probably call them French fries.

456.85.text:
So it's made up of chips
covered in a mincemeat.

460.48.text: You can use different meats, I suppose.

462.01.text:
- You can choose other meats.
- Yep, and then a brown--

464.51.text: Which was hard to get back then, as well.

465.79.text:
Brown sauce. So it's just
using very few ingredients

467.99.text:
because of the rationing
and because of trying to find--

470.79.text: Quite a backstory to this one.

472.98.text:
Seems like you're
compensating for something.

476.47.text:
- All right. I'm ready.
- So is it real or fake?

482.83.text: Ooh, time for me to tie it up.

487.37.text:
- That looks good, guys.
- Squidgy fiddlesticks.

490.26.text:
- Is that dogfood in the middle?
- (Barry snickers)

493.79.text:
You didn't make this, did you?
You got these hacks to make it.

496.53.text:
- This is not real.
- This is fake.

500.53.text:
The bloodlines, man!
This is about the bloodlines.

503.02.text: You must not be from the islands.

504.54.text:
Come here. I don't know
if you call them the islands.

506.62.text: I think you call them the isles.

508.06.text:
Don't be giving him high-fives.
You're supposed to be impartial.

511.06.text:
- Oh, we are completely impartial.
- Yeah, completely.

512.74.text:
- I hope that you like marmites.
- They can't eat that, can they?

516.51.text: (crew member) Oh, sure. Take a big bite.

518.34.text: Take a giant bite of that.

520.17.text:
- Did you say you put cat food in it?
- No.

521.42.text:
- (crew member) It might be cat food.
- That's cat food.

524.22.text: You'll eat that in Good Mythical More.

526.35.text:
- (Jamie laughs)
- Gotta get those views. Guys, sorted up.

530.70.text:
- So you'll take it really badly.
- (Rhett laughs) Yeah.

533.85.text: Come on, you can turn this around.

535.10.text:
Just in case you didn't
want to know. Thanks, Dan.

537.18.text:
- Thanks for the reminder.
- I've gotten them all right.

538.93.text:
So the next one--
now, I'm gonna be honest--

541.61.text: I hadn't heard of this before.

550.72.text:
It comes from the north of England,
so you would call it a...

556.15.text:
Yeah, in your best and
Northern Scottish accent.

562.72.text:
- It's a singin' hinny.
- Singin' hinny.

564.29.text:
- It's a singin' hinny.
- Hinny. It's a singin' hinny.

572.29.text: ...New Yorker that's been in an accident.

576.60.text:
It's like, what's wrong
with your diaphragm?

580.49.text:
Okay, so what I can
make out-- this is kind of--

582.57.text: it's like a scone. It has raisins in it.

584.56.text:
- But it's been fried in lard and fat.
- Ooh.

589.19.text:
- We have raisins in it as well.
- A deep-fried scone.

593.61.text: but just fried in animal fats.

595.58.text:
- Pan-fried, and then in the oven.
- Pan-fried.

597.19.text:
So the question is,
is it real or is it fake?

605.54.text:
I know what's from my home
country and what's not, guys.

607.72.text: Okay, so these are our singing hinnies.

614.05.text:
- And I'm being honest.
- But you didn't know about it.

616.30.text: I had no idea of them originally.

617.69.text:
We've not got any idea
what these are like.

619.23.text:
- So we want to apologize in advance.
- Oh, my goodness.

622.47.text:
- I made them this morning.
- That's some dry stuff.

625.36.text:
- Is it good? I made it this morning.
- (Rhett) Yeah.

627.28.text:
- Okay, here we go.
- Okay, so to finish us off,

636.02.text:
- Baseball team.
- They're a very-- Well, they're close.

638.69.text: They're a very popular British biscuit.

641.52.text:
Okay, so we've put a bit of jam
in between two biscuits.

645.59.text:
- Don't wink at me.
- And sometimes you also get--

649.88.text:
Sometimes you also
get a little heart cut out,

651.46.text: so you can see the jam through the top.

652.69.text:
- It was also Jamie's nickname at school.
- Yeah.

654.86.text:
- It really was.
- Jamie sounds like Jammie.

657.02.text:
- It's just got an extra M.
- Yeah, Jammie Dodger.

659.64.text:
- Yeah.
- Did you wear your PJs to school?

662.14.text:
No, I was the Artful Dodger
in a production of Oliver

666.02.text:
- when I was 12 years old.
- Okay. I like this story a lot.

668.44.text:
'Cause we call PJs jammies.
I'm ready to answer.

671.18.text:
- I know I've already lost, so whatever.
- In three, two, one...

677.99.text:
- Yeah, they're very real.
- They came in a packet.

679.88.text:
- Wow, did you make the packet?
- (Barry) They are delicious.

682.68.text: Oh, man. I am so excited about those.

684.25.text: All right, so break out the Marmite.

685.85.text:
You guys can dig into the
goodness. Now, you like this, so...

693.29.text:
- Of course I do.
- They scrape this off of the...

695.13.text: Get a spoonful, now. A spoonful.

696.67.text:
- No, a spoonful.
- That's a half. That's a half spoonful.

699.50.text:
- Okay, that's three quarters.
- Usually, we put this on toast.

702.84.text:
Never go for a full
spoonful, but you know.

706.14.text:
It smells really sweet
but musty or something.

712.06.text:
You get it in there and
see what you think about it.

714.74.text: It sticks to the spoon quite a lot.

717.17.text:
While you're trying to get
that down, I'll remind people

718.75.text:
that they can support the show
by checking out lynda.com,

721.20.text:
where you can find thousands
of online video tutorials.

723.95.text: You can learn about video editing,

727.50.text:
You won't learn how to make
a face like Link is making right now.

730.59.text: That's all his. That's all original.

732.35.text: But you'll learn lots of things.

733.68.text:
And you can get a free trial
at lynda.com/rhettandlink.

737.74.text:
(mouth partially full)
You know what time it is.

739.72.text:
- Hey, guys. I'm Lucy.
- I'm Oliver.

741.82.text:
- And I'm Emily!
- And we're from...

746.64.text:
It's time to spin
The Wheel of Mythicality!

750.40.text:
Make sure you check out
Jamie and Barry's channel, Sorted Food,

753.94.text:
on YouTube. It's amazing.
And you know what?

756.27.text:
Some people you might know
are gonna be making an appearance

758.15.text:
- on their channel a little bit later.
- Ugh!

760.57.text: Also, click through to Good Mythical More.

762.07.text:
- They got two more things for us to try.
- (Jamie chuckles)

764.21.text:
- I can't wait for that.
- (Barry and Jamie laugh)

767.07.text:
"Old Lady Knitting Competition."
That's all four of us, boys.

777.34.text:
- (high-pitched voice) I'm gonna get you.
- (yipping sounds)

780.09.text:
- I'm gonna-- I'm gon' knit.
- (Jamie snoring)

784.26.text:
- Gertrude. Gertrude, wake up. Wake up!
- Look at that.

789.36.text: It's a giraffe. I'm done. I win.
